articles.personality_title: 400,000-year-old evidence shows early humans made fire on purpose
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Around 400,000 years ago, early humans lived during a time called the Palaeolithic period. Scientists have long wondered when humans first learned to make fire by themselves instead of just using natural fires.

**What happened** – Researchers found burned soil, broken tools heated by fire, and pieces of pyrite (a mineral used to create sparks) at an ancient site in Suffolk, UK. These clues show that people back then were not just using fire by chance—they were making it intentionally. This discovery was published online in December 2025 in the journal Nature.

**Impact** – This is the oldest clear proof that early humans controlled fire by making it themselves. Fire helped them cook food, stay warm, and protect themselves, which could have changed how they lived and evolved. Finding pyrite is especially important because it suggests they had the technology to create sparks, not just catch natural flames.

**What's next step** – Scientists will study other ancient sites to see if early fire-making was common elsewhere. They will also try to learn more about how this skill spread and how it affected human culture and survival over time.

**One-sentence takeaway** – For the first time, we have strong evidence that early humans in Europe made fire on purpose 400,000 years ago, marking a key step in human history.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une preuve de 400 000 ans montre que les premiers humains faisaient du feu volontairement
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Il y a environ 400 000 ans, les premiers humains vivaient pendant la période paléolithique. Les scientifiques se demandaient depuis longtemps quand les humains ont appris à allumer le feu eux-mêmes, au lieu d'utiliser seulement des feux naturels.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs ont trouvé du sol brûlé, des outils cassés chauffés par le feu et des morceaux de pyrite (un minéral utilisé pour créer des étincelles) sur un site ancien dans le Suffolk, au Royaume-Uni. Ces indices montrent que les humains de cette époque ne se contentaient pas d’utiliser le feu par hasard – ils le fabriquaient volontairement. Cette découverte a été publiée en décembre 2025 dans la revue Nature.

**Impact** – C’est la preuve la plus ancienne que les premiers humains contrôlaient le feu en le fabriquant eux-mêmes. Le feu leur permettait de cuire la nourriture, de se réchauffer et de se protéger, ce qui a pu changer leur mode de vie et leur évolution. La présence de pyrite est importante car elle suggère qu’ils savaient créer des étincelles, pas seulement utiliser des flammes naturelles.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont étudier d’autres sites anciens pour voir si la fabrication du feu était courante ailleurs. Ils chercheront aussi à comprendre comment cette compétence s’est répandue et comment elle a influencé la culture et la survie humaines.

**Phrase clé** – Pour la première fois, nous avons une forte preuve que les premiers humains en Europe fabriquaient le feu volontairement il y a 400 000 ans, marquant une étape clé de l’histoire humaine.
articles.personality_title_es: Evidencia de hace 400,000 años muestra que los primeros humanos hacían fuego a propósito
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Hace unos 400,000 años, los primeros humanos vivían durante el período paleolítico. Los científicos han preguntado por mucho tiempo cuándo aprendieron a hacer fuego por sí mismos, en lugar de solo usar fuegos naturales.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores encontraron suelo quemado, herramientas rotas calentadas por fuego y pedazos de pirita (un mineral usado para crear chispas) en un sitio antiguo en Suffolk, Reino Unido. Estas pistas muestran que las personas de esa época no solo usaban el fuego por casualidad, sino que lo hacían intencionalmente. Este hallazgo se publicó en diciembre de 2025 en la revista Nature.

**Impacto** – Esta es la prueba más antigua y clara de que los primeros humanos controlaban el fuego haciéndolo ellos mismos. El fuego les ayudaba a cocinar, mantenerse calientes y protegerse, lo que pudo cambiar su forma de vivir y evolucionar. Encontrar pirita es importante porque indica que tenían la tecnología para crear chispas, no solo para usar llamas naturales.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos estudiarán otros sitios antiguos para ver si hacer fuego era común en otros lugares. También tratarán de entender cómo se difundió esta habilidad y cómo afectó la cultura y supervivencia humana.

**Frase clave** – Por primera vez, tenemos una fuerte evidencia de que los primeros humanos en Europa hacían fuego a propósito hace 400,000 años, marcando un paso clave en la historia humana.

articles.title: The European Commission has paid Poland 76 million euros from the Solidarity Fund for flood relief
articles.summary: In September and October 2024, intense and prolonged rainfall caused widespread flooding in many countries of Central and Eastern Europe.
articles.content:
In September and October 2024, intense and prolonged rainfall caused widespread flooding in many countries of Central and Eastern Europe.

The European Commission has paid out 76 million euros from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to Poland and 32 million euros to Austria. The funds will be used to help combat the effects of the floods of autumn 2024. At the same time, Cyprus received 2.3 million euros in support to help deal with the consequences of the fires that hit the country in July 2025.

The funds were transferred to Poland and Austria after the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union (the Member States) approved the European Commission’s request to release them.

In September and October 2024, intense and prolonged rainfall caused widespread flooding in many Central and Eastern European countries. Support from the Fund is intended to help rebuild infrastructure, including transport and water and sewage systems. The Fund can finance rescue and repair operations retroactively – from the first day of the disaster.

Cyprus applied for assistance from the Fund in October 2025 after fires in July destroyed infrastructure in the Limassol and Pafos regions, including schools and healthcare facilities. (8.12.2025)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant financial aid disbursement from the European Union Solidarity Fund to multiple countries affected by natural disasters, enabling recovery and rebuilding of critical infrastructure. This has broad societal impact by supporting disaster relief and infrastructure restoration, benefiting large populations in Central and Eastern Europe.
articles.personality_title: European Union provides 110 million euros to help flood and fire recovery in Poland, Austria, and Cyprus
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In late 2024, heavy and long-lasting rains caused severe flooding across Central and Eastern Europe. Later, in 2025, Cyprus faced destructive wildfires that damaged important buildings.

**What happened** – The European Commission released a total of 110 million euros from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to support recovery efforts. Poland received 76 million euros and Austria 32 million euros to repair flood damage from autumn 2024. Cyprus was given 2.3 million euros in 2025 to help rebuild after wildfires destroyed schools and healthcare centers.

**Impact** – These funds help countries fix roads, water systems, and other essential services damaged by disasters. This financial support allows rescue operations and repairs to start quickly, even covering costs from the first day of the disaster. It shows how European countries work together to recover from natural events that disrupt daily life.

**What’s next step** – The money will be used in the coming months to rebuild infrastructure and improve safety in affected areas. This will help communities return to normal and prepare for future emergencies. Other countries experiencing disasters may also apply for help from the Solidarity Fund.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The European Union has provided over 110 million euros to support Poland, Austria, and Cyprus in rebuilding after floods and fires, helping restore vital services and protect communities.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’Union européenne débloque 110 millions d’euros pour aider la Pologne, l’Autriche et Chypre à se remettre des inondations et des incendies
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – À la fin de 2024, de fortes pluies prolongées ont provoqué de graves inondations en Europe centrale et orientale. Plus tard, en 2025, Chypre a subi des incendies dévastateurs qui ont endommagé des bâtiments importants.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La Commission européenne a versé un total de 110 millions d’euros issus du Fonds de solidarité de l’Union européenne (FSUE) pour soutenir les efforts de reconstruction. La Pologne a reçu 76 millions d’euros et l’Autriche 32 millions d’euros pour réparer les dégâts causés par les inondations de l’automne 2024. Chypre a obtenu 2,3 millions d’euros en 2025 pour reconstruire après les incendies qui ont détruit écoles et centres de santé.

**Impact** – Ces fonds aident les pays à réparer routes, systèmes d’eau et autres services essentiels endommagés par les catastrophes. Ce soutien financier permet de commencer rapidement les opérations de secours et les réparations, même en couvrant les coûts dès le premier jour de la catastrophe. Cela montre la solidarité entre pays européens face aux événements naturels qui perturbent la vie quotidienne.

**Prochaine étape** – L’argent sera utilisé dans les mois à venir pour reconstruire les infrastructures et améliorer la sécurité dans les zones touchées. Cela aidera les communautés à retrouver leur vie normale et à mieux se préparer aux urgences futures. D’autres pays victimes de catastrophes peuvent aussi demander de l’aide au Fonds de solidarité.

**Une phrase clé** – L’Union européenne a fourni plus de 110 millions d’euros pour soutenir la Pologne, l’Autriche et Chypre dans la reconstruction après les inondations et les incendies, aidant à restaurer les services essentiels et à protéger les populations.

articles.title: Banks to tell you where you might put your money
articles.summary: Targeted support will allow banks and financial firms to make suggestions on how to handle savings.
articles.content:
Banks to tell you where you might put your money

5 hours ago Share Save Kevin Peachey Cost of living correspondent Share Save

Getty Images

People who might otherwise turn to friends, family, or social media influencers for financial advice are to be given new help to invest their money. Targeted support from registered banks and other financial firms is being given the go-ahead by the City regulator and should start in April. This will allow firms to make investment and pensions recommendations based on what similar groups of people could do with their money. It still falls short of individually tailored advice, which can only be provided by an authorised financial adviser for a fee.

Nearly one in five people turned to family, friends or social media for help making financial decisions, according to a survey by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA). Sarah Pritchard, deputy chief executive of the FCA, said the new regime would be "game changing". "It means millions of people can get extra help to make better financial decisions," she said. "We also hope it will build greater confidence to invest. While investing will not be right for everyone, we know people in the UK invest less compared to the EU or US."

'Advice gap'

Investing money is not an option for millions of people. The regulator said that one in 10 people had no cash savings, and another 21% had less than £1,000 to draw on in an emergency. However, FCA data suggested about seven million adults in the UK with £10,000 or more in cash savings could receive better returns through investing. Investing does come with some risk as the value of an investment can go down as well as up, but the spending power of cash savings can be eroded by rising prices. The regulator said that many consumers who were in a position to invest but chose not to did so because they were unsure of their options, felt overwhelmed, or needed more support. Only 9% of people surveyed received regulated advice on their pensions and investments in the 12 months to May 2024. Targeted support aims to bridge a gap between general guidance and information, and financial advisers who charge a fee. For example, banks could explain how a large pot of cash savings could be invested, or how investments could be spread out to reduce risk. "The FCA's new rules mark a significant step towards closing the advice gap and will empower millions," said Yvonne Braun, director of policy at the Association of British Insurers.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a new regulatory initiative allowing banks and financial firms to provide targeted investment support to millions of people who currently lack access to affordable financial advice. This has broad societal significance by potentially improving financial literacy, confidence, and wealth-building opportunities for the general public, addressing a large advice gap. The story is focused and provides sufficient context about the problem and the expected impact.

articles.title: Did ancient humans start farming so they could drink more beer?
articles.summary: New evidence suggests that alcohol was a surprisingly big motivator in our monumental transition from hunting and gathering to farming – but was beer really more important to us than bread?
articles.content:
New evidence suggests that alcohol was a surprisingly big motivator in our monumental transition from hunting and gathering to farming – but was beer really more important to us than bread?

Koron/Getty Images

Whatever you’re tucking into this festive season, chances are you didn’t have to kill it yourself or forage it from the wild. For that, you can thank your ancestors who, starting around 10,000 years ago, pulled off one of humanity’s most dramatic transformations: they began shifting from their traditional lifestyle of hunting and gathering to become farmers.

Why this happened is puzzling, given that our species had survived successfully for around 300,000 years without having to reap and sow – not to mention milk, shear and shepherd. Many ideas have been put forward as possible explanations. Maybe farming offered a more reliable source of food. Maybe it allowed people to be less dependent on their neighbours. Maybe it was about wanting to stay in the same place, perhaps because a particular location had religious significance or loved ones were buried there.

Or was it more about getting wrecked with your mates? That might sound laughable, but, then as now, alcohol would have gone beyond being a source of pleasure (hangovers notwithstanding) and provided a means of social bonding. We know networking has been central to human success, and if you want to lubricate these relationships regularly with beer or other alcoholic beverages, you need a reliable supply of cereals. So, did our ancestors upend their lives for a tipple?

Anthropologists have been pondering this possibility since the 1950s. However, they didn’t have the technology back then to test the idea. The challenge is to distinguish between beer and bread, which is considered by many to be a more likely candidate for driving the rise of farming. Baking bread and brewing beer look superficially similar in the archaeological record, says Jiajing Wang at Dartmouth College in New Hampshire. Both involve grinding up cereals and mixing them with water, leaving starchy residues. Researchers needed a way to distinguish beer starch from bread starch. They also needed to be able to tell which was older.

As a result, a handful of archaeologists, including Wang, have spent years on what may seem like a quixotic effort: to find evidence of the oldest alcoholic brew.

Subscriber-only newsletter Sign up to Our Human Story Each month, Michael Marshall unearths the latest news and ideas about ancient humans, evolution, archaeology and more. Sign up to newsletter

A good starting point was the later settled societies, like ancient Egypt, where beer-making was glaringly apparent. Egyptian archaeological sites often contain distinctive pottery jars. “They literally just call it a ‘beer jar’”, says Wang, because its shape resembles a fermentation tank. In the past few years, she and her colleagues have confirmed that these were used to brew and store alcohol by identifying telltale microscopic remains preserved inside. At Hierakonpolis in southern Egypt, for example, they found beer jar fragments containing starch granules from cereals, yeast cells and crystals of calcium oxalate, or “beer stone”. These showed that people there were making beer from a mixture of wheat, barley and grass between 5800 and 5600 years ago – more than 2000 years before the first pharaoh of a unified Egypt.

A rice alcohol pot from Qiaotou, Zhejiang province, southern China, that is between 8700 and 9000 years old Jiajing Wang

“Those people were making beer at a quite industrial level,” says Wang. These early beverages weren’t like modern ales or lagers, though. “They sprouted the grains, and they cooked them, and then they used wild yeast to convert some of the sugary stuff into alcohol,” she says. The result wasn’t a clear liquid, but a “sweet, slightly fermented porridge”.

Such findings have provided a blueprint for the kind of evidence that can demonstrate prehistoric beer-making. The next challenge was to see just how far back in time such evidence could be found.

In 2016, Li Liu at Stanford University in California, Wang and their colleagues described a site called Mijiaya in northern China, where pottery vessels revealed traces of beer brewing 5000 years ago. The Mijiaya people used an unusual mix of plants for their beer: broomcorn millet, another kind of millet called Job’s tears, barley and tubers. Five years later, Wang and Liu described similarly ancient evidence of boozing at the Xipo site near the city of Xi’an in northern China, which contains artefacts from a culture called Yangshao. Rice and millet were fermented in large vats using a red mould called Monascus, which is still used to make fermented foods such as rice wine, as part of a starter called qu. They suggested that elite people consumed the beer during “competitive feasts”.

The oldest alcoholic brew

The oldest evidence, however, is from the Shangshan culture on the lower Yangtze river in southern China. Discovered by Liu and her colleagues two decades ago, it is one of the earliest farming societies, dating from between about 10,000 and 8500 years ago. In 2021, a team led by Wang described a Shangshan site called Qiaotou, which is between 8700 and 9000 years old. It is a mounded platform several metres high, surrounded by a ditch. There are no houses on the mound. Instead, it is dotted with burials, accompanied by painted red pottery. The Shangshan people were “wonderful, highly skilled pot-makers”, says Wang. On the pottery, the team found traces of rice, Job’s tears and unidentified tuber-like growths used to brew beer. The rice beer may have been consumed during funeral feasts or buried with the dead, she says.

Then, a year ago, Liu and her colleagues described the oldest evidence of brewing in East Asia to date. Her team had examined 12 pottery sherds from the deepest layer of the original Shangshan site, which is between 9000 and 10,000 years old. “This represents the earliest phase of Shangshan culture,” she says. The sherds carried traces of rice, other cereals like Job’s tears, acorns and lilies – and the remains of a qu starter that contained Monascus and yeast.

At this time, “domestication was already ongoing”, says Liu, and clearly so was beer-making. This is all compatible with beer being a major driver of domestication. “There’s a surplus of alcohol production because you have a cereal surplus,” she says.

Compatible, but not proof, unfortunately. Because it turns out that the oldest bread long predates the Shangshan beer – and, indeed, the advent of farming. At Shubayqa 1 in Jordan, archaeologists have found evidence of “bread-like products” from between 11,600 and 14,600 years ago. The people who made this early bread were Natufians, who are known to have often settled down in one location for extended periods of time. Nevertheless, they got almost all their food by hunting and gathering.

Rice terraces in Guangxi province, China Sebastien Lecocq / Alamy Stock Photo

To complicate things further, it turns out that these hunter-gatherers also appear to have brewed beer. Raqefet cave in Israel was a Natufian burial site, where about 30 bodies were interred. There, Liu, Wang and their colleagues found three stone mortars that had been packed with multiple wild plants, including wheat, barley and legumes, and then left to ferment, producing a porridge-like beer. The vessels dated from between 11,700 and 13,700 years ago – evidence that brewing also predates farming.

The question of whether beer or bread came first remains unresolved. “We still don’t have hard evidence to answer that,” says Liu. It is similarly unclear whether beer or bread – or something else – was the main motivation for the farming revolution that would eventually provide the food and drink on your festive table.

“I wouldn’t be surprised if both were the motivations,” says Wang. After all, history is never simple: why would prehistory be any different?
articles.reasoning: The article presents a significant archaeological and anthropological discovery about the origins of farming and alcohol production, revealing new insights into human history and social development. This knowledge enriches our understanding of early human culture and the factors driving major societal changes, which has broad educational and cultural significance.
articles.personality_title: Ancient beer brewing may have helped start farming 10,000 years ago
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – About 10,000 years ago, humans changed from hunting and gathering to farming. This was a huge change in how people lived and got their food. Scientists have long wondered why this change happened.

**What happened** – New research shows that making beer might have been a big reason why people started farming. Archaeologists found ancient pottery in China and Egypt that still had tiny remains proving beer was brewed there thousands of years ago. Some of these beer-making sites are as old as 10,000 years, around the same time farming began.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because it suggests social reasons, like sharing beer at gatherings, could have pushed humans to grow grains instead of just hunting or collecting wild plants. Before this, many thought bread or just food needs were the main reasons for farming. Finding evidence of early beer shows humans valued alcohol for social bonding even back then.

**What's next step** – Scientists want to keep studying ancient sites to find more clues about early beer and bread. They hope to understand better which came first and how these drinks and foods influenced human choices. This will help explain how farming really started and how early societies worked.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Ancient beer brewing likely played a key role in the start of farming by encouraging humans to grow grains for social drinking thousands of years ago.
articles.personality_title_fr: La fabrication ancienne de la bière a peut-être aidé à démarrer l’agriculture il y a 10 000 ans
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Il y a environ 10 000 ans, les humains sont passés de la chasse et de la cueillette à l’agriculture. Ce fut un grand changement dans la façon dont les gens vivaient et obtenaient leur nourriture. Les scientifiques se demandaient depuis longtemps pourquoi ce changement avait eu lieu.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – De nouvelles recherches montrent que la fabrication de la bière pourrait avoir été une grande raison pour laquelle les gens ont commencé à cultiver. Des archéologues ont trouvé de la poterie ancienne en Chine et en Égypte contenant de minuscules traces prouvant que la bière y était brassée il y a des milliers d’années. Certains sites de fabrication de bière sont vieux d’environ 10 000 ans, à peu près au moment où l’agriculture a commencé.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle suggère que des raisons sociales, comme partager de la bière lors de rassemblements, ont pu pousser les humains à cultiver des céréales au lieu de seulement chasser ou cueillir des plantes sauvages. Avant cela, beaucoup pensaient que le pain ou simplement les besoins alimentaires étaient les principales raisons de l’agriculture. Trouver des preuves de la bière ancienne montre que l’alcool avait déjà une valeur sociale.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques veulent continuer à étudier des sites anciens pour trouver plus d’indices sur la bière et le pain anciens. Ils espèrent mieux comprendre ce qui est venu en premier et comment ces boissons et aliments ont influencé les choix humains. Cela aidera à expliquer comment l’agriculture a vraiment commencé et comment fonctionnaient les premières sociétés.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La fabrication ancienne de la bière a probablement joué un rôle clé dans le début de l’agriculture en encourageant les humains à cultiver des céréales pour boire socialement il y a des milliers d’années.
articles.personality_title_es: La antigua fabricación de cerveza pudo haber ayudado a iniciar la agricultura hace 10,000 años
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Hace unos 10,000 años, los humanos cambiaron de cazar y recolectar a cultivar alimentos. Este fue un gran cambio en cómo las personas vivían y obtenían su comida. Los científicos han preguntado por mucho tiempo por qué ocurrió este cambio.

**Qué pasó** – Nuevas investigaciones muestran que hacer cerveza pudo haber sido una gran razón por la que la gente comenzó a cultivar. Arqueólogos encontraron cerámicas antiguas en China y Egipto con pequeñas pruebas que demuestran que allí se hacía cerveza hace miles de años. Algunos de estos lugares para hacer cerveza tienen unos 10,000 años, casi al mismo tiempo que empezó la agricultura.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento es importante porque sugiere que razones sociales, como compartir cerveza en reuniones, pudieron motivar a los humanos a cultivar cereales en vez de solo cazar o recolectar plantas silvestres. Antes, muchos pensaban que el pan o las necesidades de comida eran las razones principales para la agricultura. Encontrar evidencia de cerveza antigua muestra que el alcohol ya tenía valor social.

**Próximos pasos** – Los científicos quieren seguir estudiando sitios antiguos para encontrar más pistas sobre la cerveza y el pan antiguos. Esperan entender mejor cuál fue primero y cómo estas bebidas y alimentos influyeron en las decisiones humanas. Esto ayudará a explicar cómo realmente empezó la agricultura y cómo funcionaban las primeras sociedades.

**Resumen en una frase** – La antigua fabricación de cerveza probablemente jugó un papel clave en el inicio de la agricultura al motivar a los humanos a cultivar cereales para beber socialmente hace miles de años.
